column2: Do plants feel?
column3: Do plants have nervous responses (of a sort) similar to those of animals?
column4:
Bose was a leading physicist of his age and pioneered the investigation of microwave optics in the late 1800s. He made the first public demonstration of radio communication and is also credited with proving plants have nervous responses similar to those of animals.


--Indo-Asian News Service

For clarifications/queries, please contact IANS NEWS DESK at 
2616-5778/8546, 2617-3369 or mail us at
support@eians.com
Dr.J.C.BOSE
 
 
 
Challenges

When anything new is discovered, there will always be people who question it. The results of Bose's work, too, were not accepted by all. There were people who challenged them and even said that there was not much truth in them. Bose gave a lecture at the Linnean Society next year to a gathering of scientists. He explained with suitable experiments how plants respond to stimuli. Even those who had challenged him could not find fault with his experiments or conclusions.

There is an interesting story about a demonstration that Bose gave in England. On that day he wanted to show some new things that he had found out. He had come to the conclusion that plants can feel pain like animals; that when we pinch them they suffer; and that they die in a few minutes after they are poisoned. Bose wanted to show experiments to prove these conclusions. A number of scientists and other leading men and women had gathered to hear him. Bose started the experiments by injecting poison into a plant. The plant should have shown signs of death in a few minutes. On the contrary, nothing happened. The learned audience started laughing. Even at this adverse moment Bose showed admirable calmness. He thought quickly. The poison that he injected into the plant did not kill it. So, he supposed that it would not hurt him also. With full confidence he got ready to inject the poison into himself. At that instant a man got up and confessed that instead of poison he had put similar colored water. Now, Bose conducted the experiment again with real poison, whereupon the plant withered and died as expected.

Jagadishchandra Bose continued his work and made new discoveries. He found that plants shrink a little during the night. He found out why plants always grow towards light even if they have to bend. He also found out the reason why some plants grow straight and some do not. He explained that this was due to the 'pulsation' in plants. This pulsation quickens by heat and slows down by cold in plants.

Jagadishchandra Bose did remarkable work, - and scientists outside India had honoured him. Yet there were people who opposed him. As a result even the Royal Society delayed publishing his valuable work in its publications, But nothing could make him give up his work. He was sure that years of research had led him to the truth. So he did not feel that it was very necessary to depend on scientific journals only. He wrote books and published them on his own.

By this time Bose had made a name for himself as a great scientist. The instruments he had developed were being used in some Western countries too. He visited Europe and America in 1907 and 1914; scientific institutions invited him to explain his discoveries. He visited Japan also.

Most of us have seen a peculiar kind of plant called the mimosa (touch-me-not') which spreads on the ground. It has very small leaves. It is extremely sensitive. If we just touch one leaf, that leaf and the leaves nearby all fold up. The greater the force we use, the larger the number of leaves which fold up. The whole row of leaves of the branch can be made to fold like this by touching it with a little greater force. Why does only this plant react like this? We have often wondered, haven't we? Bose wondered, too. And he went on to find out. He found that other plants also react to a man's touch in the same way. The only difference is this: We cannot see the reaction of other plants but we can see the reaction of the mimosa. But Bose wanted to study th

column2: How can I put a lean on someones house?
column4:
As usual with legal-related questions on Yahoo! Answers, far too little information exists to answer the question adequately.

The term is "lien."  It is a "legal right or interest that a creditor has in another's property, lasing usu[ally] until a debt or duty that it secures is satisfied - Typically, the creditor does not take possession of the property on which the lien has been obtained."

You're getting ahead of yourself here, though.  Depending on state law, you'll need to have a formal lender or creditor relationship before you'd be able to attach a lien.  Also, much depends on whether the loan is recourse or non-recourse - was this a debt to the person, or to the property?

Regardless, your first action should be to go to small claims court and file a claim against the debtor.  Contact your local district court in whatever state you're in, and ask them about the maximum ceiling for a small claims action.  Determine from there where you'd be able to bring you case, and then whether you'd need to consult a lawyer.

EDIT: For a debt of $10,000, you need to consult an attorney and explain the situation.  The attorney will advise you how to proceed and what your chances are.

column2: why do americans call football soccer.?
column3: where does the term soccer originate.
column4: It's a contraction of 'Association Football.' The term originated in England in 1863, because there were already other forms of football at the time. Australia, Canada, Ireland, New Zealand and South Africa also call it 'soccer' or 'association football.' Italy calls it 'calcio.'

column2: How is the decoder for SECA 2 satellite TV work?
column4:
This article should help:

http://www.nds.com/press_room/article_sky_italia_290404.html


The SECA encryption system was originally deployed in Italy in 1997 by Telepiu, which then was a subsidiary of Canal Plus, whose subsidiary, Canal Plus Technologies, supplied the system. The initial version deployed by SECA was known as SECA I and in May 2002 this was replaced by SECA II. In July 2003 Canal Plus Technologies was acquired by Thomson and in turn in January 2004 the business was acquired by Nagra. 

SKY Italia was formed on 1 May 2003 by the merger of Telepiu and Stream. At that time Stream operated with the encryption systems Irdeto, SECA and NDS. SKY ceased operating the Irdeto encryption system in February 2004. 

Presently, SKY has more than 2.5m digital customers. Of these, 1.9m utilise SECA decoders and the remainder use NDS decoders. SKY anticipates it will replace approximately three-quarters of the 1.9m SECA decoders currently deployed, with the remainder requiring only a new smart card. 

Existing SKY SECA subscribers will be progressively converted to NDS transmission, commencing from may 2004. In some cases this will be done by SKY providing a new NDS smart card which will operate in existing SECA decoders, but for many subscribers SKY will be delivering an NDS decoder and smart card to the subscriber's home at no additional cost. 

At this time SKY subscribers using a SECA enabled decoder need to take no action: SKY will contact each subscriber directly during the next six months to advise if it will supply them with a new decoder or a new smart-card. 

SKY's CEO Tom Mockridge said: "To ensure ongoing security of transmission and to achieve the efficiency and stability of a common software platform it is necessary to use only a single encryption system and SKY has chosen NDS to be its single encryption system in the future". 

This decision means from 13 June SKY will stop selling subscriptions that use the SECA card. To provide an opportunity for potential subscribers currently owning or wishing to purchase a SECA enabled decoder, SKY is making a special offer for "smart card only" subscriptions from April 28 until 13 June. For subscribers using credit card or RID payment method the special offer will include the first month's subscription free of charge (on all packages). The usual activation fee of EUR 59 will continue to apply and all smart cards sold will need to be activated prior to 30 June. SKY accepts the obligation to provide an NDS decoder and smart card to all customers accepting this offer at the time SECA transmission is terminated. 

From 14 June, after this special offer finishes, SKY will no longer sell subscriptions which use SECA enabled decoders. All new customers will be supplied with a NDS enabled decoder. 

A. Media Background 

The SECA encryption system was originally deployed in Italy in 1997 by Telepiu, which then was a subsidiary of Canal Plus, whose subsidiary, Canal Plus Technologies, supplied the system. The initial version deployed by SECA was known as SECA I and in May 2002 this was replaced by SECA II. In July 2003 Canal Plus Technologies was acquired by Thomson and in turn in January 2004 the business was acquired by Nagra. 

SKY Italia was formed on 1 May 2003 by the merger of Telepiu and Stream. At that time Stream operated with the encryption systems Irdeto, SECA and NDS. SKY ceased operating the Irdeto encryption system in February 2004. 

Presently, SKY has more than 2.5m digital customers. Of these, 1.9m utilise SECA decoders and the remainder use NDS decoders. SKY anticipates it will replace approximately three-quarters of the 1.9m SECA decoders currently deployed, with the remainder requiring only a new smart card.

column2: Is it good for couples to do things apart for the holidays?
column3: My live in boyfriend is Jehova Witness and doesn't celebrate christmas, is it still okay for me to celebrate it with my family back home and leave him for the holidays?
column4:
Yes, it is okay to leave your 'Jehovah's Witness' boyfriend alone for the holidays. If he is really a 'good' (though struggling) Jehovah's Witness, there are many many reasons he might feel uncomfortable to accompany you during holidays with your family.

1. He may still feel bad a little bad about 'fornicating' with you, and certainly doesn't want to look your family in the eye while they 'know'.

2. Participation in Christmas celebrations by a Jehovah's Witness is considered 'apostasy', a sin much worse than fornicating.

3. Loving you is a heart thing; it may be easy for him and others (like his mom) to understand that "sin". On the other hand, decking the halls (etc) is NOT an emotional urge, and maybe neither he nor his mom (he guesses) could excuse that decision even in their own minds

4. His background may cause him to feel genuinely offended at the commercialism, inaccuracies in Christendom's version of Christ's birth, the pagan origins, the unscriptural traditions and the hypocrisy too often associated with Christmas.

Let your boyfriend know that he is welcome to come (if he really is), but that you understand and accept his decision to stay home.

column2: how to typecast a List object into ArrayList object in java ?
What is the difference b/w endolymph & perilymph in human ear?
column4:
Endolymph- watery fluid in the membranous labyrinth of the ear.
Perilymph- watery fluid between the membranous and bony labyrinths of the ear.

The perylimph is similar but not identical in composition to extracellular fluids of the body, such as cerebrospinal fluid. The concentration of sodium ions in the perylimph is high (about 150 milliequivalents per litter) and that of potassium ions is low (about 5 milliequivalents per litter).

Endolymph is a totally unique extracellular fluid, which ion composition is unlike anywhere in the body. Potassium ions major in endolymph and virtually no sodium. Because endolymph is unlike any other, the processes which are maintained and regulated cannot be extrapolated by other fluid system. The total ion content of endolymph is significantly higher than that of perilymph.

column2: In the statement ReseltSet res=statement.executeQuery("select * from emp")--if emp table has no rows then
column3: wt's will be the value of res in Java ?
column4: You will get an empty ResultSet. Note that empty does not mean that the ResultSet is null. You can find out whether the ResultSet is empty by calling either first() or next() on the ResultSet and checking the return value. If it is true, i.e. there is a first (or next) tuple, the ResultSet is not empty. If the return value is false, the ResultSet is empty.\n\nif (res.next()) == false) ... // res is empty

column2: Is it alright to take a break from your friends?
column3: I just need to know becuz I see my friends all the time and sometimes they really get on my nerves. It is good to take a break right?
column4: Maybe what you need are some new friends, not necessarily leaving the ones you have. Just broaden your circle of friends. A circle of friends should include at least one who keeps you on track...one who will always be straight with you and tell you when you're being stupid. You should be able to know that you can tell your friends anything, and it won't get broadcasted all over the city...trust. You should be able to have fun with your friends and have shared interests. That doesn't mean you always agree with everything they say. It means that you like some of the same things they like and you can do them together. Your friends should never be threatened by you bringing another friend into your circle, because your friends are like your extended family and are an extention of you. If your friends want you to be exclusive to them only, it may be time to find all new friends. No one should own your friendship. If your friends call and want to go somewhere and you don't, it should be ok to let them know you just don't feel like going out with them right now. They should be secure in your relationship that you don't have to spend all your time with them in order to remain close friends. You don't have to see your grandparents every day in order for them to continue to love you. It's the same with friends. Friendship should never be conditional, based on how much time you put into it. But, a certain amount of maintenance IS required to keep your relationship close. If you're wanting a break, it sounds like they're requiring more of you than you want to give. So, maybe just take up a new hobby for a while and see if it makes things go a little better for you. <*)))><

column2: What is the source of morals for someone who does not believe in any kind of god?
column3:
This is an honest question. I want to know what you really think about this. Anyone who has a religion or some kind of god, has a basis for their morals, the laws that their god gives them. 

(I'm saying "god" with a little "g" because I'm including all religions in this)

What is the origin of morals for an atheist? If you say, "your conscience" then what if in someone's conscience, they believed that it was ok to hurt other people? what gives you the authority to say they are wrong? there would be no basis for the law in a completely atheist society. 

I'm not criticizing anoyone for not having a religion, I just want an honest answer. What is the origin of your morals? If you say it was your parents, then where did they get them from? obviously somewhere along the line, they came from some form of religion. Honestly, what is your opinion?
column4: Being athiest doesn't mean you don't value life, I think if you value life that's enough to base morals off of your conscience.  How much you value life and living is what most laws are based on anyway so in a completely athiest society as long as the majority value life(which most would since the majority of people do) you could base the law off of that value since law isn't based on religious morals it's just based on preserving and respecting life.\n\nI'm athiest and my morals probably do come a bit from my parents, but mostly I just try to do what I feel is right.  The majority of athiests I know wouldn't deny that the morals in most religions are good things to adopt, they just don't want all the other crap that comes with the religion.  I have no problem following the golden rule, but I don't believe that I should have to scare myself into following it because I don't want to go to hell or dissapoint Jesus or whatever.  I believe that morals came before religion and that religion is just one way invented to get people to adopt the morals and to follow laws. If people are made to believe that there are eternal consequences for their actions they'll be more thoughtful before acting.  In the human society there are certain things you have to do to keep alive and to live well and they just happen to be more complicated than in the societies of other animals. The morals most of us have today are a survival instinct, we learned early on in our society that working together would help us thrive and in order to get people on your side you have to treat them a certain way and act a certain way yourself.  I think morals are more of a basis for religion than religion a basis for morals...religion needs morals but morals don't need religion.

column2: is yahoo better or google?

column2: discuss the vibrational frequencies of SiH4 molecule?
column4: If you were going to discuss the vibrational frequencies of SiH4, I suppose you would want to compare it to something similar, like CH4.  Both of these molecules have 5 atoms, and are tetrahedral in shape.  That indicates that there will be 3N-6 modes, or 3(5)-6 = 9 vibrations.  The symmetry of these modes are governed by group symmetry rules, yielding an a1 stretch (1), an e bend (2), a t2 antisymm stretch (3) and a t2 bend (3), accounting for the nine modes.  Comparing to CH4, the vibrational frequencies (energies) for those modes that involve Si atom motion would be depressed due to the increased mass of Si.  An exception would be the a1 symmetric stretch as that should not involve Si motion.

column2: Tell me about the history of football?
column3: Who invented it ? how is it played
column4:
History of Football 
 From Mary Bellis,
Your Guide to Inventors.
FREE Newsletter. Sign Up Now! 

American football was started in 1879 with rules instituted by Walter Camp.
Derived from the English game of rugby, American football was started in 1879 with rules instituted by Walter Camp, player and coach at Yale University.

Walter Camp
Walter Camp was born April 17, 1859, in New Haven, Connecticut. He attended Yale from 1876 to 1882, where he studied medicine and business. Walter Camp was an author, athletic director, chairman of the board of the New Haven Clock Company, and director of the Peck Brothers Company. He was general athletic director and head advisory football coach at Yale University from 1888-1914, and chairman of the Yale football committee from 1888-1912. Camp played football at Yale and helped evolve the rules of the game away from Rugby and Soccer rules into the rules of American Football as we know them today.
One precursor to Walter Camp's influence was William Ebb Ellis, a student at the Rugby School in England. In 1823, Ellis was the first person noted for picking up the ball during the soccer game and running with it, thereby breaking and changing the rules. In 1876, at the Massosoit convention, the the first attempts at writing down the rules of American football were made. Walter Camp edited every American Football rulebook until his death in 1925.

Walter Camp contibuted the following changes from Rugby and Soccer to American football: 

one side retained undisputed possession of the ball, until that side gives up the ball as a result of its own violations 
the line of scrimmage 
11 on a team instead of 15 
created the quarter-back and center positions 
forward pass 
standardized the scoring system, numerical scoring 
created the safety, interference, penalties, and the neutral zone 
tackling as low as the knee was permitted - 1888 
a touchdown increased in value to six points and field goals went down to three points - 1912
The NFL or the National Football League, was formed in 1920.

column2: whats the best way to sell my house FAST without losing too much money?

Has the foreclosure been published yet? You will have at least 90 days (and probably 120) to close the house from the start of foreclosure. Unfortunately, you haven't much time to negotiate. How "hot" is your market? You migh want to see if your Realtor will take a 5% listing, keeping 2% and offering 3% on the MLS. Hope this helps

column2: Why do hotdogs come in packages of 10, but buns come only in packs of 8?
column4:
It isn't true you end up in an endless purchasing cycle - and it's easy to work out where the cycle ends via product of primes:

10 = 5*2
8 = 2*2*2

Our hotdogs and buns converge at 5*2*2*2, or 40

That's 4 packs of hotdogs and 5 packs of buns.

column2: Is it possible to build a device capable of time travel but wouldn't work due to the enormous power it needs?
column4:
If you actually care, read "Time Travel In Einstein's Universe" by J. Richard Gott.  It actually proposes multiple ways this is possible.

My favorite which I learned in physics class is the fact that velocity warps time.  The closer you get to the speed of light, the slower time moves for you. I've read this, and it is definately true, we had to derive the formula in physics, and calculate the time, lenghth(which decreases with speed), and mass (which increases with speed) distortion as well. The new time which has passed is equal to the time passed of a stationary observer over one minus the square root of velocity squared over the speed of light squared.  The effects of this are very negligable unless you are moving at speeds very very close to the speed of light, at least over 90% of the speed of light, and we haven't gotten anywhere close yet.  But theoretically if you were traveling very close to the speed of light, you could rotate the earth for what seems like days to you and then have years pass on earth, thus in a way traveling into the future.  Also, it gets slower and slower so that it is thought that time would actually stop if you were moving at the speed of light, and so now what happens if you move even faster? Some think it might cause you to go back in time.  It is impossible to travel faster than the speed of light, however in his book, Gott discusses looping around strings(the strings from string theory) which warp space time, and discusses ways to "beat" light and actually show up someplace before you left.

Time definately slows down with velocity, therefore time travel definately occurs, however, i actually have a problem with the time travel of humans.  Because along with time dialating, mass also dialates, and length contracts, if we were to approach speeds significant enough to distort time, our mass would increase and length would decrease.  Now since density is mass over volume, wouldn't that mean that our density would increase dramatically? wouldn't our blood then become so dense and viscous that it prevents blood flow and our cells become deprived of oxygen and we die? Because of this, I find it unlikely that we will ever be able to time travel, but if we can accelerate objects enough, we will probably eventually be able to send other things into the future.

column2: Which is correct? "He is better than me." or "He is better than I (am)."?
column3: I believe "better than I" is correct because the word "am" is implied at the end of the sentence.  \n\nThank you.
column4: The key is apparently the word "than". The following is a quote from American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language at education.yahoo.com. \n\n Since the 18th century grammarians have insisted that than should be regarded as a conjunction in all its uses, so that a sentence such as  Bill is taller than Tom  should be construed as an elliptical version of the sentence  Bill is taller than Tom is.  According to this view, the case of a pronoun following than is determined by whether the pronoun serves as the subject or object of the verb that is "understood." Thus, the standard rule requires  Pat is taller than I  (not me) on the assumption that this sentence is elliptical for  Pat is taller than I am  but allows  The news surprised Pat more than me,  since this sentence is taken as elliptical for  The news surprised Pat more than it surprised me.  However, than is quite commonly treated as a preposition when followed by an isolated noun phrase, and as such occurs with a pronoun in the objective case:  John is taller than me.  Though this usage is still widely regarded as incorrect, it is predominant in speech and has reputable literary precedent, appearing in the writing of such respected authors as Shakespeare, Johnson, Swift, Scott, and Faulkner. It is also consistent with the fact that than is clearly treated as a preposition in the than whom construction, as in  a poet than whom (not than who) no one has a dearer place in the hearts of his countrymen.  Still, the writer who risks a sentence like  Mary is taller than him  in formal writing must be prepared to defend the usage against objections of critics who are unlikely to be dissuaded from the conviction that the usage is incorrect.·Comparatives using as . . . as can be analyzed as parallel to those using than. Traditional grammarians insist that  I am not as tall as he  is the only correct form; in formal writing, one should adhere to this rule. However, one can cite both literary precedent and syntactic arguments in favor of analyzing the second as as a preposition (which would allow constructions such as  I am not as tall as him).
